loans.use: To purchase sheep meat.

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en:
Narantuya is 46 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a house in Zavhan province, Mongolia. Her older daughter, age 25, is a salesperson, while the younger two attend college and secondary school. Her husband is a fireman who works at Central Heating Place in Zavhan province. 

She manages a Mongolian traditional-clothing-making business in a rented workshop. She makes stylish and colorful clothing called "Deel." People in Mongolia like to wear Deel during national holidays. She is a hardworking lady who says, "I have received loans from XacBank many times and am still planning to receive more in the future." 

She is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase a more advanced, modern sewing machine for her business.

loans.use: to purchase a more advanced, modern sewing machine

loans.name: Asunción Transito

texts.es:
La Señora. Asunción V. es socia del banco comunal Libertad en Progreso, vive por la comunidad de Sayausi en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es la tercera ciudad mas importante del país, su clima es frió pero su gente tiene un corazón muy cálido y mantienen su cultura y tradiciones.

Doña Asunción tiene 63 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos quienes son mayores de edad, sus dos primeros hijos son casados e independientes, su ultima hija tiene 30 años de edad y sufre de síndrome de Down. Su esposo es jubilado, con el trabajo en su juventud han logrado construir su casa propia.
 
La Señora. Asunción se dedica a la venta de frutas, esta actividad la desempeña hace 11 años, trabaja de domingo a domingo desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 5 de la tarde, tiene su puesto propio en un mercado de la ciudad.

Es socia del banco comunal hace 3 años y su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de frutas para incrementar su negocio.

Su meta es agrandar su negocio.
texts.en:
Sra. Asunción V. is a member of the Communal Bank “Libertad en Progreso” (Freedom in Progress). She lives in the community of Sayausi in the city of Cuenca, the third largest city in Ecuador. Even though the climate is cold, the people have very warm hearts and are able to maintain their culture and traditions.

Doña Asunción is 63 years old, married, and has three adult children. Her first two children are married and independent. The youngest daughter is 30 years old and suffers from Down syndrome. Her husband is retired. As a result of the work they performed when they were younger, Asunción and her husband were able to build their own home.

Sra. Asunción has been selling fruit for 11 years. She works Sunday through Sunday from 8am to 5pm. Asunción has her own stand at the city market. She has been a member of her Communal Bank for three years. Her new loan will be invested in the purchase of fruit in order to increase business.

Her goal is to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fruit.

loans.name: Saranchimeg

texts.en:
Saranchimeg is 52 years old and lives with her husband in a house in Zavhan province, Mongolia. All her children are grown up and live separately. Her husband is a retired man who stays home all day. 

She manages a clothing-trading business in her town. She started her business in 2006 with a loan received from XacBank. Since then she has gained much experience and built a strong customer base. She is a polite woman who says, "I am happy to have a chance to receive loans." 

She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase summer clothes from China.

loans.use: to purchase summer clothes from China

loans.name: María Evangelina

texts.es:
La Señora. María P. es socia del banco comunal Libertad en Progreso, vive por la comunidad de Sayausi en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es la tercera ciudad  mas importante del país, su clima es frió pero su gente tiene un corazón muy cálido y mantienen su cultura y tradiciones.

Doña María tiene 32 años, es casada y tiene 4 hijos de  9, 7, 5 y 1 año de edad, sus tres primeros hijos estudian en la escuela. Su esposo es de profesión albañil, con el trabajo conyugal han construido su casa propia.
 
La Señora. María se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar,  allí cría ganado, ovejas, chanchos, gallinas y cuyes que son para su consumo y para la venta. También se dedica a bordar pero solo bajo pedido.

Se encuentra en el segundo crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y lo va a invertir en la compra de más animales.
 
Su meta es de tener un local propio para vender sus bordados.
texts.en:
Sra. María P. is a member of the Communal Bank “Libertad en Progreso” (Freedom in Progress). She lives in the community of Sayausi in the city of Cuenca, the third largest city in Ecuador. Even though the climate is cold, the people have very warm hearts and are able to maintain their culture and traditions.

Doña María is 32 years old, married, and has four children (ages 9, 7, 5, and 1). The first three children attend school. Her husband is a mason by profession and they worked together to build their own home.

Sra. María takes care of the household chores. She also raises sheep, pigs, chickens, and guinea pigs for personal consumption and to sell. In addition, María makes embroideries but only when she has orders.

She is receiving her second loan from the Communal Bank and will invest in the purchase of more animals. Her goal is to have a shop where she can sell her embroideries.

loans.use: to purchase animals.

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Nergui is 31 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in a house in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her older son is in secondary school while the younger one hasn't reached school age and stays home. 

She works as a cook in a restaurant with a monthly salary of 180,000 MNT. In addition, she manages a transportation service business with the help of her husband. Mainly they transport wood, coal and construction materials and sell them in the center of the province.  

Their business was quite profitable, which allowed them to build their own house last year. They are hardworking people who say, "We are planning to expand our business for the future." 

Nergui is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase wood to sell.

loans.use: to purchase wood to sell

loans.name: Amarbayasgalan

texts.en:
Amarbayasgalan is 25 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in Uvs province, Mongolia. His two sons stay home with their mother. 

He manages an animal hides trading business with the help of his friend. He started his business at his stall at a local market. Besides sheep and goat skins, he sells variety of metal and iron for traders. This kind of business is very profitable in local areas of Mongolia. 

He is planning to continue and expand his business independently for the future. He works hard in order to feed his family, and he managed to buy a plot of land to build a house. Right now his earnings are the only source of income for their family. He is an open-minded and polite man who says, "I want to have my own trading center in the future." 

He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase sheepskins for his business.

loans.use: to purchase sheepskins

loans.name: Batsuh

texts.en:
Batsuh is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Uvs province, Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in his parents' backyard. He manages a vegetable-trading business with the help of his wife. 

He started his business in 2007. Now he owns 2.5 hectares of land where he plants daily consumption vegetables including potatoes, carrots and cabbage, etc. He harvests 40-45 tons of vegetables every year. His wife is responsible for selling their vegetables. 

He is planning to have their own plot of land, which will allow him to build a house for his family. He is a polite man who says, "I want to buy a cow for my parents, so they can drink milk every day." 

He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a cow and some seeds for his business.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and some seeds

loans.name: Batbold

texts.en:
Batbold D. is 23 years old and lives with his wife and daughter, age 2, in Uvs province, Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent. 

He manages a shoemaking business in cooperation with his wife. They started their business by making Mongolian traditional shoes in 2007. They make fashionable and unique shoes that satisfy their customers’ special demand. Now they are among the more experienced shoemakers with many regular customers. 

Since their business began they have developed and improved it immensely and have been able to upgrade their living conditions. 

They are planning to have their own workshop in the future. 

Batbold is a hardworking man who says, "We will do our best to develop our business further."  

He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase leather, glue, yarn and some other materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase leather, glue, yarn and some other materials.

loans.name: Embuu

texts.en:
Embuu S. is a 63-year-old widow who lives alone in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Uvs province, Mongolia. All her children are grown up and live separately. 

She manages a clothing-trading business in her town. She started her business in 2006. In addition she also sells fruits in order to supplement her earning. Her children help her during their spare time. Her business has already stabilized and developed. 

She is a polite and open-minded woman who says, "One can achieve in fulfilling his dream if he works hard." 

She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her clothes-trading business.

loans.name: Doong

Marianna is a very open person. She is able to provide excellent client service. People love to buy from her and come back again. Recently Marianna started a second location. Now she needs a loan to purchase more inventory to put on her new shelves.

loans.name: Saidmalik

texts.en:
Saidmalik U. is married and has two sons. His wife is a hardworking housewife and works in agriculture at their home. Saidmalik is a taxi and cargo taxi driver. Three to four times a month he leaves for the route to Dushanbe and Kurgantube. He works hard to improve his family’s living conditions and has been in this business for 20 years.

Saidmalik has a small income.  The loan that he received previously from Imon International helped him to start and improve his business. Saidmalik requests a $2000 loan to repair his vehicle so that he can provide better services and convenience for his clients. 
   
About Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which began soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To repair transportation vehicle

loans.name: Mina's Group

texts.en:
Mina K. is the treasurer of this group. She is 52 and married to a taxi driver. Together with her husband she has raised two daughters and a son. The daughters study at university. The son got married a year ago. He lives and works in Russia. Two years ago, Mina got a loan in the amount of 10 000 soms, purchased three sheep and started breeding livestock animals. She resold that livestock at good price and repaid that loan successfully. Since that time, Mina has been breeding livestock. She hopes to obtain the new loan in order to purchase more livestock for breeding. Each month Mina saves some money, so in the near future she plans to purchase a vehicle for the family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida C. is from the village of Balide, Aurora Zamboanga del Sur. She is 35 years old. Loida is single and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Loida provides a waste management service with tricycle transport. Loida has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 7100 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Loida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Loida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Loida is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to repair existing engine. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Loida from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing engine.

In order to earn money to meet the family needs Beishenbubu takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national blankets, pillows, cloth and dressmaking supplies. She started this activity in 2001 with the initial investment of 1000 soms and now she earns 3500 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more fabrics and materials for sewing. In the future Beishenbubu plans to start repairing the house.

texts.en:

Mrs. Sarun Chhun is a tailor, while her husband has full-time employment. She hopes to start a new business raising pigs, so she is asking for her first loan of $300 to purchase piglets and feed for pigs.

Working hard to help provide for her family's needs, Jean grows rice and corn to sell at the market. She is requesting funds to purchase seeds and fertilizers and is hopeful that the loan will help to improve her harvest. Jean wants to earn more to be able to sustain her children's education.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn, 43, is from the village of Tuyabang Bajo, Oroquieta City. She is married with two adult-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn runs a snack vending business in her local community. She has been engaged in her business for 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities. 

Merlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP to purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business. This will be her 10th loan cycle with PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Sinoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Sinoeun C. and his wife, Mrs. Chanthorn Phorn, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have one young daughter.

Sinoeun has full-time employment and his wife is a chef, cooking for a restaurant. Sinoeun’s wife has asked for a loan to buy a motorbike for commuting. As the couple commutes to work at different times, Sinoeun is now asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase another motorbike for his commute. He will also use part of the loan to build a staircase in his house.  

Photo: Sinoeun is standing next to the motorbike which he wants to buy.

With money received from this loan she wants to purchase three livestock animals for breeding. In the future she wants to see her children get wed and save some money to purchase a vehicle for the family.

loans.name: Nusura

texts.en:
Nusura M. is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. Nusura has a salon business, which she has run for four years.
To help expand her business, Nusura has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase hair oil and braids for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Nusura hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase hair oil and braids for resale.

loans.name: Zarbibi

texts.en:
M. Zarbibi is 54 years old. She is a purposeful woman who is married and has 10 children. Zarbibi is engaged in trading and she started her business with glass vases and clothes. Today she sells flour in the market of Dehqon. She heard about Imon International from other businessmen. In the future she would like to cooperate with Imon International in order to expand her business and open her own store. Zarbibi would like to get a loan of 8000 Somoni for purchasing flour and expansion of her business. 
   
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy flour.

She applied for a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for her harvest to improve.

Joelynda is 46 years old, married and has five children. She hopes for her children to have bright futures.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina is a 52-year-old lady who lives in Bakunase Village. Dina is married and has been blessed with four children and also has an adopted child. Her children are:
-	Melinda, 26 years old 
-	Stevanus, 23 years old and studying in a university in Surabaya
-	Benyamin, 22 years old and studying in a university
-	Martir, 15 years old and in the third grade of Junior High School
-	Tasya, 3 years old (adopted child).

Currently Dina is running a kiosk business and it is going well but Dina was thinking to initiate another business which is breeding piglets and cattle. She thinks that this business can help her in generating more income for her family’s well-being and her children's education costs. But she realized that she does not have enough money to buy piglets and cattle. 

She was lucky when she met a TLM field officer who provided her with information on TLM Individual Lending Program. She is really interested in joining the program. She is now requesting a loan of IDR 10,000,000. She plans to utilize the loan to buy piglets and cattle to raise as well as to buy fodder.  Dina hopes that TLM will help her by providing a loan for her new business.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and cattle to raise as well as to buy fodder.

loans.name: Norvel

texts.en:
Norvel is a 26-year-old single man who lives with his family in Liliba Village. Norvel has been running a tailoring business for three years, a skill taught by his mother. From his business income Norvel helps his parent meet their living expenses and finances his siblings who are still at school. But his income is not sufficient to fully support his family. 

Norvel met a TLM field officer who explained about the Individual Lending Program for small entrepreneurs like him so he submitted a loan application to run a retail business to generate more income. Fortunately, there is an empty small building owned by his family in front of his house. He is requesting a loan of IDR 4,000,000 to purchase business stock such as instant noodles, sugar, coffee, detergents, biscuits, etc to sell in his kiosk. Norvel is really hoping that TLM will approve his loan application.

loans.use: to purchase inventory: instant noodles, sugar, coffee, detergents, biscuits, etc.

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité NGHA GNON MOUTA est créé le 26 mai 2001. Il est composé de 06 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même village. Elles ont formé leur groupe par affinité et par voisinage. Leur principale activité est le petit commerce de fruits de saison. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de NIAGUIS NEMA. 

Madame Fariniane Mané est veuve et mère de huit (08)enfants. Elle a également la charge de sept (07) autres personnes.

Elle exerce un commerce de diverses marchandises: citron, miel, balais, huile de palme... Elle possède une bonne expérience dans ce domaine puisqu'elle exerce depuis plus de cinq ans.

Avec ce crédit, elle va acheter du citron, du miel, de l'huile de palme et des balais.

Ce prêt lui permettra de réaliser des revenus supplémentaires, afin de bien prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Ngha Gnon Mouta was created on May 26, 2001. It is composed of 6 women who are all from the same village. They formed their group based on friendly and neighborly ties. Their primary activity is selling seasonal fruits. The group is part of the Niaguis Nema banc villageois.

Mrs. Fariniane Mané is a widow and the mother of eight (8) children. She is also taking care of seven (7) other people.

She makes a living selling various commodities such as lemons, honey, brooms, palm oil, etc. With over five years of experience in this field, she has a good command of her activity.

She plans to use this loan to buy lemons, honey, palm oil, and brooms.

The loan will help her to increase her revenue and better look after her family.

loans.use: to buy lemons, honey, palm oil, and brooms

loans.name: Linet

texts.en:
Linet is 44 years old and has been in active farming for the last 20 years in her home area of Kitale in Western Kenya. She is married with four children, two adults and the others of school age. Her farm produces maize, beans and tomatoes with the help of two farmhands.

Linet has made a request for a loan from Juhudi KIilimo amounting to 70,000 KES to expand her poultry project by buying more birds and constructing a poultry unit for the birds. She hopes the loan will improve her income and support the family in terms of food provision. Linet points out that poultry feed has become expensive and animal diseases are also common.

loans.use: to buy more poultry

loans.name: Lubrino

texts.en:
A. is from the village of Palayan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 23 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, A. runs a fish food stall in the market. 

A. has been engaged in her business for 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month. She joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP to purchase more and different kinds of fish for her stall. This will be the third loan taken out by A. from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Peterson

texts.en: Peterson is 26 years old, single and has made a living by running a car wash for the last three years. He has done well and now has four employees. He used to run a barber shop, but membership in Faulu Kenya allowed him to buy car-washing equipment and dig a well to get the water his business needs. In the future, he hopes to own rental houses. He is applying for a loan for 60,000 Kes to expand his business by buying a buffing machine, detergents, water tanks and a water pump.

loans.use: to buy equipment for a car wash.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 48 years old, married and has five children, the oldest of whom is 23 years old. For the last 22 years, she has made a living by farming rice and raising pigs. She sells her pigs at the local market and makes about 8,000 PHP a month from her work. She has applied for a loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and farm supplies. She hopes to increase her income because this will allow her to save for her children's future.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more goats and coffee for resale.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is currently in the business of selling bedsheets, clothes and table cloths. She is 29 years old, married, and has four children, only two of whom go to school. 

Rita took out a loan to stock more bedsheets, clothes and table cloths to sell. She hopes to buy a piece of land and construct a concrete house for her children in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more bedsheets, clothes and table cloths to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a business-lady and a member of a group in Faulu Kenya. She has been running a grocery store for over twenty years. Rose, a mother of eight, says that she works hard in her business so as to provide for her family. She hopes to open other branches of her business in the future. She needs 25,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy oranges, bananas, kale, and cabbages.

loans.use: To buy oranges, banana, kale, and cabbages.

loans.name: Ola

texts.en:
Ola is a 29-year-old wife and mother of one son. Her husband who is photographed here instead of her as she is a religious woman has a photography studio.

Ola's husband wanted to purchase a new and modern  printing machine for pictures that would enhance the pictures' quality and make the work faster to serve a larger number of customers.

loans.use: Purchase a modern printing machine for pictures.

loans.name: Joash

texts.en:
Joash is a father of three children between one and six, and lives with his family in Kitale, Western Kenya. His been farming for five years, producing potatoes, maize, milk, and beans which are all sold at the local market. Joash subsidizes his farming income with a hotel business he runs in the local town. 

Joash has made a request for a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry birds which he believes will have a great impact on his productivity and his family's living standards. He is optimistic that his farming business will triple in five years. 

Joash however notes that fluctuating market prices and climatic conditions are still a challenge to farmers. He adds that Juhudi Kilimo loans have increased small farmers' living standards.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds

loans.name: Nancita

texts.en:
Nancita is engaged in farming and hog-raising businesses. She grows corn and vegetables. She also raises pigs in her backyard. Nancita sells her harvest and grown pigs at the market. 

Nancita requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. Nancita hopes to be a successful businesswoman someday. 

Nancita is 48 years old and is a married woman. She has three children aged 19, 18, and six.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine N. K. is 67 years old, married, and has seven children.  She has a dairy farm, which she has run for 13 years.  Apart from dairy farming, she grows tea to supplement her income.  Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, she has witnessed growth in her business.  She is looking forward to adding more cows to her farm.  She is requesting a loan for 20,000 KES, which she will use to buy animal feeds.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds

loans.name: Samah

texts.en:
Samah is a 38-year-old single woman from Rafah in Gaza Strip. Samah has managed to have her own beauty salon and has established a good reputation for her stylish work and good relations with customers.

Samah, who appears in the picture here, took out a loan from FATEN to purchase creams and hair products for beauty salon use. Samah received a number of training courses to ensure the best services for her clients; she is known for her good reputation, commitment and punctuality.

loans.use: to purchase creams and hair products for beauty salon use.

loans.name: Diyaa

texts.en:
Diyaa’ is a 23-year-old single man. His father passed away and so he lives with his brothers. In order to be able to support the family, Diyaa’ went to work at a coffee shop and gained some experience there.

Using his experience Diyaa’ decided to open a small humble coffee shop as a start in Al Mafraq, and because of his young age and his sociable character he was able to get a lot of regular customers, such as young men like him, taxi drivers who take their cup of coffee away and other people from the area who go there to have a good time together.

Diyaa’ has been running his business for a year now, but since the coffee shop is built of nylon sheets and wood, he thinks it is time for him to build a real coffee shop. He also wants to add some nice decoration to it so he can give his customers a great place to sit at while enjoying their leisure time, and that’s why he applied for a loan.

loans.use: To build his own coffee shop.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy earns a living through farming. She grows rice to sell. She currently needs farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers. She applied for a loan so that she could fund her farm. Nancy hopes for her farm to grow.

Nancy is 45 years old and is a married woman. She has six children and the oldest is 23 years old. Her husband works as a farmer and driver.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is from the village of Villaflor, Oroquieta City. She is 26 years old, married and has two infant children. To make a living, Joy runs a clothing sales business in the local community. Joy has been engaged in her business for 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities. She joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. 

Joy is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP with which she will purchase more clothes for her clothing business. This will be her 1st loan taken out from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for her clothing business.

location.town: Purok 2 Villaflor Oroquieta City Misamis Occidenta

loans.name: Jesse

texts.en:
Jesse is aged 34 years and married with two children aged 6 and 3 years, with the first one already attending school. He has been in mixed farming for 10 years, producing tomatoes and vegetables which he sells to the local market. Jesse also works as a technician in the local market, doing mainly welding and battery charging.

Jesse has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes to ensure that the water supply for his poultry farm is consistent. He says steady supply of water will cut down his farm running costs and give him steady returns. He hopes to expand his farming activities and even own a tractor in future.

He notes that climatic changes are a great challenge to farming.

loans.use: To pay for purchase of a water pump, irrigation pipes and poultry.

loans.name: Phylis

texts.en: Phylis is a single mother of a three-year-old. She runs a salon to earn a living.  She has employed one person in her business.  She has managed to sustain her business for five years because of her hard work.  She hopes to stabilize her business and employ more people.  She has requested 20,000 Kes to buy shampoos, a hair dryer and hair chemicals.

loans.use: To buy shampoos, a hair dryer and hair chemicals.

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon is a farmer who lives in Surallah, South Cotabato with his family. He is married and has kids. Farming is the main source of livlihood of Ramon's family. Ramon works hard to earn a living from his farm. He makes sure his rice crops are growing healthily. Ramon also put up a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages. The store helps in their daily needs.

Ramon's loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He hopes to expand his rice farm in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Ravelyn

texts.en:
Ravelyn is a 25-year-old married woman from Surallah, South Cotabato. She has a 4-year-old child. Ravelyn is engaged in farming and hog-raising businesses. She helps her husband till their land for growing rice. She also maintains a small backyard piggery. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market.

Ravelyn has requested a loan and plans to use it to buy pig feed, rice seeds and fertilizers. In the future, she hopes to be a successful businesswoman. She also hopes for her child to have a bright future.

loans.use: to buy pig feed, rice seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ainagul's Group

texts.en:
Ainagul I., 48, is the leader of this group. The story of this entrepreneur is a typical scenario for most of the residents of the small town Tyup. Being in a remote area, the town offers only a few entrepreneurship options for its residents, including small businesses like cattle breeding and reselling, agricultural products and commerce. 

Ainagul was not an exception and chose to cultivate her land and sell agricultural products in a local market. But in 2001, after a rich harvest of garlic and potatoes, Ainagul undertook a decision, which became a turning point in the further development of her life as a business lady. Ainagul invested all generated revenue in the purchase of young livestock, which amounted to 5,000 soms. The whole family made small contributions to the family business, however, currently the youngest nineteen-year-old son shows a significant help. 

Ainagul’s husband is an experienced construction worker, but he believes that business is a major and stable source of income in a current and future family budget. Ainagul gets 7-8 liters of milk every morning and provides local residents with milk products every morning. Ten years of running this business have ensured Ainagul and her family confidence in tomorrow’s stability and steadiness. A monthly income of 3,000 soms allows her to save. 

Recently the savings were used for finishing up the construction of the house where she resides. Ainagul is happy about her accomplishments and is eager to try something new. The loan from Kiva will help Ainagul buy four head of sheep for fattening and reselling. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Bekzat's Group

texts.en:
Bekzat B., 25, is a member of this group. He resides in the village of Tyup. He is married and is a young father of two children. In the past he used to have a joint business with his parents, but two years ago he started an individual business. He bought land and cultivated it. Also he runs a dairy business, selling 7-8 liters of milk for 11 soms per liter  on a daily basis.  His initial capital was 7 000 soms, while nowadays the business generates 3 000 soms per month. The purpose of the loan is the purchase of seeds. The field work has already started, so Bekzat along with other farmers is in a hurry. 

          --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase seeds.

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira A., 47, is the leader of this group. She is married and has seven kids, the youngest of whom is 14. With the help of her husband and children, she runs a family business. She has been a farmer for 18 years. Recently the revenues from a rich harvest were spent on purchasing livestock. Now she is learning the techniques of looking after cattle. Her initial capital was 3 000 soms and her monthly revenue is 6 000 soms. The purpose of the loan is the purchase of three head of livestock for further reselling.  Gulmira would really like to do major repairs on her house in future.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta is from the village of Manamong, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 63 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Benedicta runs a business venture specializing in hog raising. Benedicta has been engaged in her business for 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities. She joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. 

Benedicta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP with which she will purchase piglets and feed for them. This will be the second loan taken out by Benedicta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed for them.

loans.name: Beishekan's Group

texts.en:
Beishekan A., 60, is the leader of this group. During one of the evening conversations at the family table, after a hard workday in the field, Beishekan and her husband, a tractor driver, were thinking about government regulations in the country’s agriculture that would certainly affect their family, too. It was the year 1996, a period when new independent countries, including Kyrgyzstan, were privatizing land, which used to be collective farms during the Soviet Union. 

Beishekan saw advantages like having an opportunity to manage the business on her own behalf without participation of the government. But there were also risks of facing thorough competition and lack of experience in supplying the products. For the following fifteen years Beishekan has been running a dairy business, while her husband is most of the time in fieldwork. Several head of livestock yield up to six liters of milk daily, which Beishekan delivers immediately to local consumers for 11 soms per liter. 

Beishekan is also a proud mother of nine kids, most of whom already live on their own. For her the most successful accomplishment in her entire lifetime is giving her kids broader opportunities to choose who they want to be. Since agriculture is a seasonal business, during slow times the only source of income is the dairy business. Beishekan used a start-up capital of 3 000 soms. Now her business generates 2 000 soms of monthly income. The purpose of the loan is the purchase of 1 ton of potato seeds. The fieldwork season has started, so Beishekan says the seeds have to be sown as soon as possible.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more poultry.

loans.name: Ritchel

texts.en: Ritchel D. is 30 years old and married.  She and her family live in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato. She is a farmer and primarily grows rice to sell to rice traders. Ritchel also raises pigs and sells them at the market and runs a sari-sari store where she sells items like coffee and chips. Ritchel earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from her businesses.  She plans to use her loan to buy pig feeds, seeds, and fertilizers. In the future, she hopes her children are successful.

loans.use: to buy pig feeds, seeds, and fertilizers

loans.name: Chabagan's Group

texts.en:
Chabagan K. is  50 years old and a leader of this group. She is a resident of Tokmok. For many years, Chabagan taught Russian language and literature in a local high school. Her husband is a coach in the same high school. Twelve years ago following the advice of her relatives, Chabagan purchased cattle and gave them to her younger brother for care. The initial investment was 10,000 soms with a monthly revenue of 1,000 soms. Chabagan says it is enough for every day purchases. She is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase two calves for fattening and reselling. She hopes to have a big household in the future. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase calves

loans.name: Patriciah

texts.en: Patriciah K. M. is 29 years old, single, and has one child.  For seven years, she has been operating a pharmacy to earn a living. She also owns a quarry, where she earns additional income.  She joined a group, where the group members guarantee each other's loans, so that she would get financial support.  She hopes to own a big clinic in the future. She is requesting a loan for 20,000 KES, which she will use to buy medicines such as piriton syrup and panadols.

loans.use: To purchase medicines

loans.name: Dilbarkhan

texts.en:
Dilbarkhan B. is 37, married, and has five children. She has been engaged in breeding cattle since 2002, which she started with the initial capital of 7,000 KGS. She worked hard and managed to develop a farm with three cows and 10 sheep. Dilbarkhan has additional revenue from working as a wool comber in the local area. Her husband works as an inspector at the Batken power station and helps Dilbarkhan in breeding. 

Dilbarkhan is requesting a loan of 100.000 KGS, which she will use to purchase more cattle in order to expand her business. It will allow her to save money for her children’s education and help her dream come true – maintaining of a huge farm with a large number of cattle.  

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Yusra

texts.en:
Yusra, 51 years old, is a mother for nine children, 6 girls and 3 boys. She is married to Mousa, 52 years old, who has two jobs, one as a heating technician and the other as owner of a grocery store.

Yusra felt the need to help her husband in raising their nine children, so she started her embroidery business ten years ago. Yusra is specialized in embroidering traditional dresses and has been successfully running her business since then.

Now Yusra is applying for a loan to buy more fabrics and other raw materials so she can continue making these beautiful traditional dresses.

loans.use: To buy more  fabrics.

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto is a hard-working father to kids aged 17 and 9. He is a married man who lives in Surallah, South Cotabato with his family.

Roberto is engaged in farming and hog-raising businesses. He primarily grows rice crops to sell. Roberto raises his pigs in his backyard piggery. He earns about 10,000 PHP per month from doing these activities. He wants to improve his earnings and be able to save for his children's future.

Roberto plans to use his loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Flor

texts.en:
Flor is from the village of Villaflor, Oroquieta City. She is 66 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Flor runs a business venture in the agriculture sector, specializing in flower gardening. 

Flor has been engaged in her business for 20 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities. Flor joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.

Flor is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP with which she will purchase fertilizers and flower seeds for her flower-gardening business. This will be the second loan taken out by Flor from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and flower seeds for her flower gardening business.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a 38-year-old business lady who operates a cafeteria.  She started the business in 2009.  She has benefited from Faulu Kenya because she has met other entrepreneurs; they share a lot of business ideas.  She has also been motivated to work hard in her business.  She has requested 20,000 Kes which she wants to use to buy a refrigerator and furniture.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and furniture.

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura T., 37, is the leader of this group. She resides in the town of Toktogul with her husband and their five children, the youngest of whom is 6. Ainura’s husband is a construction worker in a local company, while Ainura relies on cattle-reselling in order to make a living. 

Ainura considers having five children a luxury, therefore she invests a big portion of the family income in the children’s development costs like education, healthcare and social life. However she remembers a period five years ago, when the family faced a harsh financial downturn and Ainura had to sacrifice her monthly income by investing it in the--in those times--risky purchase of  livestock. The risk has paid back. 

A few years later, Ainura’s household increased, and so did sales. She has experience in coping with any kind of livestock except poultry. This time Ainura is eager to try something new like adding several types of poultry to her household. With this purpose she addressed Kiva lenders. She is full of enthusiasm and strength to work further and always try something new. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is a resident of the Kitale area in Western Kenya, aged 61 and married with five children all adults save for the last-born. She has been doing  mixed farming for  over 30 years with her produce of milk, maize and beans going to the local market.

Annah has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry for her farm. She says she wants to rear both broilers and layers at the same time to ensure consistent production. She says the income will go into meeting other family needs like food.

Annah says poultry diseases are their greatest worry in the business.

loans.use: To pay for more poultry.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for his general store.

loans.name: Ddembe Women's Group

texts.en:
56-year-old N. Kokowe has been unwavering in her tenacity and determination to continue her long success and longevity in her used clothing sales business in Buikwe-Lugazi. Her enterprise has been in existence for the past 40 years and the good-natured mother of seven says she has soaked up all the invaluable business experience all this while. 

What has made her business successful is the fact that she always strives to get her clients what they require. She has combined this with her good human relationship skills and her humility. She says these have been an integral part of her business round. 

Prior to this, N. says she was preoccupying herself with a farming business, which she has since dispensed with. At present, she also ekes out side profits from a cattle sales business. Weekly, her sales revenue totals up to shillings 100,000 and she says with this Kiva loan, she is going to purchase more bales of used clothing to resell.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of used clothing to resell.

loans.name: Jamiyla's Group

texts.en:
Jamiyla J., 50, is the leader of this group. She is married and has five children. Jamiyla’s husband has been engaged in cattle breeding for a long time, which yielded enough start-up capital for building a foundation for a second family business. 

Eight years ago Jamiyla bought a spot in the largest trading center of the town. She stocked her small shopping place with the most necessary household appliances bought wholesale. The retail of technology requires big expenses and technical skills at operating the machines, however it brings desirable profit too. The business helps with tuition fees of her two oldest children, who are college students. 

The initial capital of 100,000 soms has paid back in several months. Now their monthly income reaches 50,000 soms. However a big portion of it is put back into the business, making necessary consumer purchases impossible. Jamiyla claims that the family needs vital things in order to have proper living conditions. This loan she plans to spend on a refrigerator for their house in order to keep food fresh. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a fridge.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay college fees to pursue further studies.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
26-year-old Rowena earns a living through farming and raising hogs. She tills her land where she grows rice crops. She also grows coconut trees on part of her land. Rowena raises pigs to sell. She plans to user her loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feed.

Rowena is married and has two children aged eight and three. Rowena hopes to be successful in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feed.

loans.name: Maksuda's Group

texts.en:
Maksuda K., 59, is the leader of this group. She is a widow and resides in the small town of Toktogul on her own. Three of her kids are already grown and live separately. The business story of this lady started in 2005, when she received a loan of 60 000 soms from a local bank and bought 11 head of livestock. That became a turning point in her family budget. 

Gradually she learnt more and more about care of livestock and efficient ways of selling her animals. Soon the profit helped her purchase more head of livestock. Now Maksuda’s herd is one of the largest ones in the neighborhood. A monthly income of 2 000 soms helped her repay the loan successfully. Since she has experience in taking out loans she is sure to repay the loan from Kiva, too. She requests the loan for the purchase of more head of cattle. Her biggest wish is to help her son financially in finishing the construction of his house. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira B., 50, is the leader of this group. She resides in the town of Toktogul, known for having the largest water reservoir in the country. Not many years ago a tragedy hit this family. It was the loss of Damira’s husband. In addition to a moral loss, it also was financial. He was the main breadwinner of the family, while Damira had devoted all her time to their kids. 

Later, as a widow, Damira invested 12 000 soms of family savings into acquiring a herd of livestock, which she feeds, fattens and later resells at a higher price. Currently Damira has nineteen-year-old and sixteen-year-old sons, who depend on her financially and who actively participate in cattle breeding. 

Relying on the assistance of her boys, Damira got involved in trade, too. The source for an initial capital of 12 000 soms was also a salary from teaching in a local high school. According to Damira trade has appealed to her most of all professions she experienced. It gives her chances to have direct communication with customers, study their tastes and preferences, and find things in business that need to be improved. However she wishes to continue running both businesses of cattle reselling and trade together. That allows her to increase the family capital and cover all expenses. The required loan will be spent by Damira on the purchase of four head of young livestock.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Gulzat's Group

texts.en:
Gulzat S., 22, is the leader of this group. Despite her young age, it was Gulzat, who researched the loan opportunity provided by Kiva lenders and who initiated gathering a group of entrepreneurs, who are in need of financial assistance, however are equally ambitious. 

Gulzat is single and lives with her brother, who actively takes part in the promotion of a new business. Gulzat’s care and ability to see high potential in every child has brought her to a kindergarten. She enjoys her job at a daycare and wants to continue. The story of her business started only a year ago, when she spent her full monthly salary on the purchase of one head of livestock. Gulzat’s brother takes responsibility for taking care of it while his sister’s at work. So far the reselling of  cattle generates approximately 1 500 soms a month. 

Saving a small amount allowed Gulzat purchase a long-awaited refrigerator for her kitchen. She’s proud of seeing the actual results that cattle reselling helps her achieve. Every member of the group has his or her own purposes for the loan. For Gulzat it’s the purchase of 2 head of livestock, so that she expands the business.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is from the village of Mohon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 57 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Myrna runs a business venture in the agricultural sector, specializing in hog raising. She has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities. Myrna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. 

Myrna is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP with which she will purchase feed for her hog-raising business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Myrna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her hog raising business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for poultry and a farm cart.

loans.name: Steven

texts.en:
Steven is a 44-year-old married man with five children. His oldest child is 20 years old while the youngest is seven. His wife maintains a vegetable garden.

Steven grows rice to earn a living. He tills his own land and prepares it well for growing crops. Steven has been in rice farming for 10 years. He usually earns 3000 PHP per month from his business. He currently needs seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He applied for a loan so he could fund his farm. Steven works hard to provide the needs of his family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a weighing machine and renovate her business premises.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase some beverages for resale.

loans.name: Sabenty Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Sabenty” group. They are small-scale businessmen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 to further expand their respective businesses. 

The leader of this group is Abu K.. Abu is 45; he was born in Bonkelleh village but he is currently residing in Makeni city, together with his wife and four children. His wife is a trader and three of his children are attending primary and secondary schools. Abu sells used clothes and has been doing this business for seven years now. With his share of this loan, he is going to buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: to buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy two hoes, two pumps for watering, one rake, one wheelbarrow, and to pay her workers in the farming business.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud H. is a 58-year-old hardworking man who is supporting a family of six members. He lives in a rented house in Marka.
Mahmoud was able to open his own shop where he makes different kinds of sweets and sells them. He has been working in his shop for six years now and maintains a good reputation in his area and between his competitors. Now Mahmoud has applied for a new loan to expand his shop and to add other kind of sweets to his product line.

loans.use: To purchase more sweets for his shop

loans.name: Janeffer

texts.en:
Janeffer is a resident of Kitale in Western Kenya.  She has been in the farming business for 10 years.  Her farm produces mainly maize, vegetables and milk, which she delivers to the local market. She is 31 years old and is married. She fully relies on farming for her family's upkeep.

Janeffer has made a request for a loan amounting to 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry birds for her farm. She says the poultry business will be a boost to her dairy business and will enable her to provide for her family more adequately. She is focusing on expanding both the dairy and poultry businesses so as to spread out her risks.

Janeffer points out that her farming returns are reduced by poor market prices and diseases.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds

loans.name: Bbogo Women's Group

texts.en:
Running a successful business invariably requires a combination of many factors: persistence, creativity, risk tolerance and well-defined goals. 35-year-old W. Sunday can attest to that. For 20 years now, he has been plying his fish vending business, which on the basis of its competitive nature,  calls for a lot of persistence. 

This happily married father of 8 says he began this business with savings from his agro sales business. On the side, Sunday also has a butcher shop which he says brings in additional income. Monthly, he says this business generates for him 700,000 shillings in profit.  He says with this loan he is going to buy more fish to resell and use the rest of the proceeds to pay school fees for his kids.

loans.use: to buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy timber to resell

loans.name: Rabaa

texts.en: Rabaa is 43 years old and the mother of six children. She is married to a carpenter, Mohammad, who is 47 years old. They live in a rented house in Al Zarqa. Rabaa started a small home business selling cosmetics and perfumes three years ago and has been participating in a lot of exhibitions and shows to sell her products. Now Rabaa is applying for a loan to start moving her business from a home-based business to an independent store for cosmetics and perfumes.

loans.use: To open her own store for cosmetics and perfumes.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy soaps, magi, cooking oil, etc. to resell

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en:
Maurice is 55 years old.  He has been engaged in mixed farming for over 30 years.  He produces and sells tomatoes, onions, maize, eggs and dairy. He has 6 farmhands on his farm.  Maurice is married and has 6 children, all are attending school.

Maurice has requested a loan of 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  He says this acquisition will enable him to take care of his family, including his extended relatives. He hopes to have more than four quality dairy cows in four years time.

Maurice says his farming efforts are often wasted by rampant animal diseases and poor climatic conditions.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Jean

texts.fr: Jean M. est commerçant de boutique il client d’ACB  depuis 2010.il a 31ans, marie et il a 3 enfants entre 2 ans et 11ans.  Deux de ces enfants vont à l’école. Jean est ne a Nyanza au RWANDA  et il a le niveau d’étude de ‘école primaire .il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter de ciment, sable, toles, pierre pour ravitailler sa maison.il n ya pas des difficultés attendu  de non –remboursement du credit.sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire  est de rembourser le prêt en augmentant ses ventes d’habits dans sa boutique, profiter d’avantage, et augmenter la clientèle de sa boutique.ses ambitions pour les affaires sont d’acheter un taxi minibus pour faire le transport des personnes en taxi. Pour la famille il voudrait éduquer ses enfants et construire la maison selon le plan de la ville de Kigali.
texts.en: Jean M. is a shopkeeper.  He has been a client of ACB since 2010.  He is 31 years old, married, and has three children from 2 to 11 years in age.  Two of his children attend school.  Jean was born in Nyanza, in Rwanda, and has a primary school education.  He is going to use his loan to buy cement, sand, sheet metal, and stones to make improvements to his house.   He is not expected to have any difficulties in repaying his loan.  His strategy for growing his business is to repay the loan while increasing his clothing sales at his retail shop, making larger profits, and attracting more customers to his shop.  His business goal is to buy a minibus taxi for transporting passengers.  As for his family, he would like to have his children educated and to build a house according to the city plan of Kigali.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, sheet metal, and stones to make improvements to his house.

loans.name: Nswanjere Farmers United Group

texts.en:
32-year-old Faridah N. has been operating her pharmacy business for the past 4 years in Mpigi Town. On the face of it, this happily married mother of 3 seems a courteous and down-to-earth person. From the accounts of many of her clients, Faridah is indeed a kind and approachable person. This has at length significantly impacted her business, principally from the angle of striking a chord with many clients. Over time, Faridah has established her own niche in the market. Subsequently, her pharmacy sales revenue has been increasing. 

Faridah is a trained nurse and before she ventured into the pharmacy business, she was operating a retail shop and a restaurant. Faridah also does some small-scale farming. Weekly, she says her gross business profits are about 80,000 shillings. She says with this loan, she is going to purchase more medicine to resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more medicine to resell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 49 years old and lives in Paynesville.  She has six children between the ages of 17 and 28, all of them are in school.   Rebecca operates a small stall where she sells red oil, onion, rice, etc.   To keep her customers, sometimes she sells on credit.

Rebecca is requesting a loan to purchase more red oil, onion, rice, and coal for her business.  She plans to send her children to the university and buy a car.

loans.use: to purchase more red oil, onion, rice, and coal to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cloth and threads for her tailoring business

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna is 45 years old and lives in Paynesville.  She is married and her husband is a security guard.  They have seven children between the ages of 10 and 26.  Their oldest child is working while the others are in school.

Susanna has been operating a stall where she sells many food items such as rice, red oil, salt, fish, meat, and charcoal among other items.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, red oil, salt, fish, meat, and charcoal to resell.   She plans to make her business international and send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy rice, red oil, salt, fish, meat, and charcoal to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy soap, body cream, toothpaste, etc. to resell

loans.name: Muharam
