La actividad que desarrolla Johany es la crianza y venta de aves de corral (pollos, gallinas, patos y pavos), desde hace 4 años, el lugar donde cría  sus animales en la parte anterior de la casa (donde tiene un patio grande), los alimenta con comida balanceada  y granos naturales, una vez que tengan el tamaño y el peso ideal los oferta en los distintos mercados, ya que cuenta con su propia clientela en la ciudad de Piura.  Esto le permite obtener mayores ganacias para cubrir sus gastosdiarios. 

Johany solicitau n préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2000 nuevos soles para comprar el alimento para sus animales, lo que le permitirá tenerlos bien alimentados  para venderlos a un mejor precio y mejorar el espacio o corral que tienen sus aves, para que estén más seguros.  Johany es una persona muy conocida en el lugar donde vive porque es una persona que siempre se preocupa por el bienestar de los suyos, con el ideal que en un futuro brindarles una mejor calidad de vida a su madre y hermanas.
texts.en:
Johany is 23 years old, single, and she lives with her mother and two school-aged sisters. Their home is equipped with water and electricity and it is located in La Capilla, at 20 minutes from the district of Union and one hour from the department of Piura. These regions are known for their agriculture, farming, and for their crafts.

Johany's business has been to raise and sell poultry (chicken, hens, ducks, and turkeys) for the past 4 years. She raises her livestock in the front section of her property (she has a large patio). She feeds them balanced feed and natural grains. Once they have reached an ideal size and weight she offers them for sale at the different markets. She has her own clientele in the city of Piura. This helps her have more earnings to cover her daily expenses.

Johany requests a loan from Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner) in the amount of 2000 nuevos soles to purchase feed for her livestock. This will help her keep them well fed and to sell them at a better price. She will also improve the space or corral where she keeps her poultry for greater safety. Johany is a well known where she lives because she is someone who is always looking out for the wellbeing of her own. Her ideal for the future is to provide a better quality of life to her mother and sisters.

loans.use: to purchase poultry and to improve the corral.

loans.name: Anibal

texts.es:
Anibal es un padre de familia de 35 añosde edad, vive en casa de sus padres con un hijo en edad escolar,cuenta con todos los servicios (agua, luz y desagüe), ubicada en la calle los obreros de la provincia de Chiclayo.   Ciudad caracterizada por el alto desarrollo comercial, agricultura y turismo.

Anibal labora como chofer de transporte público, en su vehículo propio haciendo taxi, esta actividad lo realiza desde hace  8 años en la ciudad de Chiclayo, al tener carrop ropio le permite trabajarlo mañana y tarde sin problemas.  Esto le permite incrementar sus ingresos diaR. quel e servira para solventar sus gastos.

Se ha visto  Anibal en la necesidad de solicitar un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 3000 nuevos soles para la reparación total y pintadode su vehículo, al no presentar ninguna falla puede ir a cualquier lugar que su cliente le diga y así puede brindar un mejor servicio, con la finalidad de tener más ingresos para poder sacar adelante a su hijo y como todo padre brindarle una mejor oportunidad en lavida.  Esto le permitirá Anibal pagar su crédito con responsabilidad y puntualidad.
texts.en:
Anibal is the father of a family and he is 35 years old. He lives in his parents' house together with a school-aged son. It is equipped with all the services (water, electricity, and sewage). It is locate don Los Obreros street in the province of Chiclayo. The city is characterized for its commercial development, its agriculture, and tourism.

Anibal works as a public transport driver, driving his own car as a taxi. he has been in the business for 8 years in the city of Chiclayo. He has his own car so he is able to work in the mornings and afternoons without any problems. This helps him increase his daily income which helps him provide for his expenses.

Anibal has seen the need to request a loan from Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner) in the amount of 3000 nuevos soles to carry out a full maintenance overhaul and paint job to his car. Without any mechanical problems he will be able to go anywhere his clients request and to provide them with a better level of service. His goal is to have more income to support his son and, as any father would, to provide him with a better opportunity in life. This will help Anibal repay his loan responsibly and on time.

loans.use: to carry out a complete overhaul of his car.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build a wall in the front of her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to make corn flour and chicha drinks.

loans.name: Julito

texts.en: Julito I. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City. He is 52 years old. Julito is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Julito runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits. Julito has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2011, Julito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julito is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods. This will be the first loan taken out by Julito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena S. is from the village of Tinabalan, Gingoog City. She is 68 years old. Lucena is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Lucena owns & operates a business selling green and yellow bananas in the local community. Lucena has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lucena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Lucena is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional green and yellow bananas. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Lucena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green and yellow bananas

loans.name: Florente

texts.en:
Florente R. Jr. is from the village of North Poblacion, Medina, Misamis Oriental. He is 33 years old. Florente is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Florente owns & operates a business providing motor sikad or habal-habal services to local community members. He also buys and sells firewood. Florente has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Florente joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florente has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory for firewood & maintenance for the motor sikad. Florente is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Florente from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for maintenance

To make a living, Noel owns & operates a business venture making and selling snacks & other delicacies like rice & cheese cakes in the local community. Noel has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Noel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Noel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients & working capital. Noel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed like sugar, flour & eggs. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Noel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Adolyn

texts.en:

To make a living, Adolyn owns & operates a business making and selling snacks & other delicacies like rice, cheese & cassava cakes in the local community. Adolyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Adolyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adolyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients & working capital. Adolyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed like flour, eggs & milk. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Adolyn from HSPFI. To make a living, Henry owns & operates a business buying and selling aluminum or stainless products like casseroles & frying pans in the local community. Henry has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Henry joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Henry has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Henry is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional products like casseroles, frying pans & other cooking utensils. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Henry from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional products like casseroles, frying pans & other cooking utensils

loans.name: Shelame

texts.en:
Shelame is from the village of Lower Langcangan, Oroquieta City. She is 26 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Shelame runs a business selling fish in the local community.

Shelame has been engaged in her business for one year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities. Shelame joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. 

Shelame is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP with which she will purchase more fish to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Shelame from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
Adelina R. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old. Adelina is married and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, Adelina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling food seasonings, spices, native vinegars, soy sauce & salt in packs in the local community. Adelina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Adelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelina is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase additional products like food seasonings, spices & canned goods. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Adelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like food seasonings, spices & canned goods

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon O. is 56 years old and married with three adult-aged children. Corazon is a farmer working in the Philippines and earns PHP 8,000 per month. 

Corazon is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to be used to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Corazon grows rice and has been doing it for almost 36 years.

In the future, Corazon hopes to have a rice crop during harvest in order to earn a higher income to support the needs of her family and to save for their future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith M. is now 45 years old and married with two school-aged children. Edith is a farmer working in the Philippines. She earns PHP 9,000 per month. 

Edith is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Edith grows rice and has been doing it for 25 years.

In the future, Edith hopes to have a large crop of rice in order to earn more income to be used in financing the education of their children. She hopes that someday she will improve their living conditions and she dreams that their children will be successful in their careers.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia E., 40, is married and has two children who are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Cynthia's sells garlic and onions in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy garlic and onions to sell in her stall.

Cynthia has been in this business for 14 years.  In the future, Cynthia would like to save enough money to provide a secure future of her family.

loans.use: To buy garlic and onions to sell in her stall

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Lucena S. works hard to support her family.

She sells garlic and onions in the Philippines and also earns additional income from farming vegetables.  

Lucena is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy garlic and onions to sell for her stall.

Lucena has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money for future needs.

loans.use: To buy garlic and onions to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Criste

texts.en:
Criste D. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 25 years old. Criste is single and has one infant child. 

To make a living, Criste makes and sells amakan or bamboo mat products to local businesses and community members. Criste has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Criste joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Criste is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials like bamboo for amakan. This will be the first loan taken out by Criste from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials like bamboo for amakan

loans.name: Gleceria

texts.en:
Gleceria M., 50, is married and has two children, one of whom is still in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Gleceria has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for three years. She requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to pay for the purchase of spare parts for her motorcycle.

In the future, Gleceria would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her child to college.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for her motorcycle.

loans.name: Triwana Sari Group

texts.en:
Ni K. J. A., 28 years old, together with all the members of this group agreed to continue borrowing from MUK. Because she already has one piglet from the profits earned from previous sales, Ni K. J. A. is using an acquisition loan to buy three more piglets. Any remainder will be used to buy pig feed needed for the 6 months' raising period.

Ni K. J. A. and her family have high hopes for the business of raising pigs that has been started up to develop profitably. She also has dreams for her children to continue their schooling at a higher level, so that their lives will be better than their parents' lives.

loans.use: To buy three more piglets and pig feed.

loans.name: Rizalina

texts.en:
Rizalina E. is a hard-working entrepreneur who makes and sells bagoong (shrimp paste) in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 25 years. Rizalina earns additional income from pig fattening.

Rizalina is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients to make bagoong.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. 

She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for making bagoong.

loans.name: Carlita

texts.en:
Carlita Y. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province.  She is 49 years old.  Carlita is separated from her spouse and has 4 school-aged children.  To make a living, Carlita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling junk food, bread, biscuits and canned goods in the local community.  Carlita has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Carlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Carlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI.  This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. 

Carlita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods and junk food.  This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Carlita from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods and junk food

loans.name: Ma. Lita

texts.en:
Ma. Lita G. is 54 years old and married with three children. 

Ma. Lita is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She has been raising pigs for six years now and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Ma. Lita has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

In the future, Ma. Lita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly P., 45, is married and has four children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Beverly has a fishing and fish-vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. 

Beverly has requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to purchase fishing equipment like fish net, etc.

 In the future, Beverly would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment like fish net, etc.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Haizel Babe

texts.en:
Haizel Babe S., 33, is married and has four children, three of whom are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur.

Haizel Babe has a fishing and fish-vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years.

Haizel Babe has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy fishing materials and to repair her fishing boat.

In the future, Haizel Babe would like to save enough money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials and repair her fishing boat.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Juviline

texts.en:
Juviline M., 34, is married and has four children who are all in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur.

Juviline has a fishing and fish-vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. 

Juviline has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials and equipment for her fishing business.

In the future, Juviline would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy materials and equipment for her fishing business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela M. works hard to support her family. 

Marcela is married and has a fishing and fish-vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 30 years now.

Marcela has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase fishing materials like fishing net and paint for the boat.

In the future, Marcela would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials like fishing net and paint for the boat.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing/fish vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for ten years now.

She requested an 18,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy materials for the repair of her fishing boat. In the future, Ofelia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy materials for repairing her fishing boat.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 43 years old and married with seven children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a coconut wine retailing business in the Philippines and requested a 29,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional coconut wine.

She has borrowed and paid off twenty-eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her coconut wine business for twelve years and also earns income from a cafeteria and from pig fattening.

Jocelyn hopes to save money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional coconut wine.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun S. is a 23-year-old man who has been living in Ornlong Veng district of Siem Reap province. He is a soldier and he earns an average of 6 USD per day. Currently, he lives with his mother who works as a farmer. Recently, her tractor broke down during the plowing process. The tractor is critical for his mother to plant rice. To help support his mother, Bun S. will be using his loan to fix his mother's tractor.

loans.use: to fix his mother's tractor

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
As a married parent of eight children, Loreta works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending.  Loreta is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fishing equipment for her fishing business.

Loreta has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephina

texts.en:
Josephina A. is 42 years old and married with four school-aged children. Josephina is a farmer working in the Philippines and earns PHP 10,000 per month. 

Josephina is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Josephina grows rice and has been doing this for almost 28 years.

In the future, Josephina hopes to have plentiful harvest in order to earn income to support the needs of her family, especially for the schooling of their children. She believes that she can improve their living conditions through the financial assistance of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Kang

texts.en:
Kang P. is a local rice farmer in the Prey Chor district. She is a good mother of 7 children, 5 of whom are single, while the other 2 are married and have moved to another house. 

From farming, Kang P. makes approximately 1.50 USD profit a day to use for family expenses. To generate additional income, her husband works as a horse cart deliverer next to his house and earns around 2 USD each day. They also have three employed children who are working in different careers in order to share their salary with them. 

Kang P. would like to ask for loan to buy a few small cows to breed and sell. Kang P. believes she can earn extra income through this Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy a few small cows to breed

loans.name: Merle

texts.en:
Merle is 50 years old and married with four children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Merle has been raising pigs for ten years and also earns additional income from rice milling.

She is borrowing 19,500 PHP through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira O. is the treasurer of this group. She is 44 years old, and unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised six children, three sons and three daughters. Most of the children are employed, and each month they provide financial support to their mom. The younger children are students, and when they are free from studying they help Gulmira with housework. 

Since 1994 Gulmira has been cultivating agricultural products. Selling some part of the harvest she earns about $88 per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase 100 liters of fuel and potato seeds. In the future Gulmira wants to get a good harvest and desires to improve the family's living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and fuel.

loans.name: Hector

texts.en:
Hector N. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 50 years old. Hector is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, he owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products, including fish like milk fish, sardines and mackerel. He uses his motorcycle in delivering and selling in the local community. Hector has been engaged in his business for over nine years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Hector joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Hector is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell, like sardines and milk fish. This will be his 4th loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Suita's Group

texts.en:
Suita B. is the leader of this group. She is 30 years old and married to a taxi driver. Together they bring up two children, a daughter and a son. The son, who is 7 years old, studies at school, and the daughter is preschool age (under seven). In order to meet the family needs Suita, together with her husband, cultivates agricultural products. 

This year Suita plans to sow 0.5 hectares of potatoes and 1 hectare of wheat. For this purpose she applied for the loan. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase seeds and some fuel. In the future Suita wants to build a new house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fuel.

loans.name: Guandulin

texts.en:
Guandulin M. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 50 years old. Guandulin is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a food stall, making and selling a variety of viands for several meals like sotanghon, chicken and pork adobo and spicy chicken or halang-halang in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Guandulin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. 

Guandulin is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients like meat, vegetables and spices. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients.

loans.name: Jhona Liza

texts.en:
Jhona Liza B. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 28 years old. Jhona Liza is single and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling colognes, deodorants, face powders and mouthwash in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $150 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Jhona Liza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She  is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional colognes and beauty products. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional colognes and beauty products.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Valentina is 47 years old and has a child who is in school. She has a restaurant business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for twelve years.

She requested a 25,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. In the future, Valentina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Vann S. is a 40-year-old woman who lives in Siem Reap province. She doesn’t have a life partner as she divorced from her husband years ago. 

She sells meat in a small kiosk along the street for earning a profit. Vann S. has been running her selling business since 2003, and she has a lot of regular customers who come to buy her meats in her wooden kiosk. 

Vann S. is now running her business very well because she sells her meats at reasonable prices and she also has good communication while selling. 

In order to increase her income, Vann S. seeks a US $500 loan to purchase additional meats to sell.

loans.use: to purchase additional meat to sell.

loans.name: Vivincia

texts.en:
Vivincia E. works hard to support her family. Vivincia is married and has a fishing and fish-vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. 

Vivincia has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase fishing equipment.

In the future, Vivincia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jyldyz's Group

texts.en:
Jyldyz K. is the leader of this group. She is 45 and married to a firefighter. Together with her husband she is bringing up three sons and two daughters. The older children study at university and the others are at school. 

Three years ago Jyldyz got a loan and purchased livestock. She made some profit reselling farm animals at a higher price after fattening them. She repaid the loan successfully and since that moment, she has been engaged in livestock breeding. 

With money received from the loan, Jyldyz wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noeun K. is 32 years old and her husband, Mr. Veasna Chhorm, is 32 years old. They live along National Road Number Six, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2000 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two are in school and the other one is still young. 

Mrs. Noeun K. and her husband are rice farmers. In addition, Mr. Veasna Chhorm also drives a motor taxi when he is not at the farm. 

Noeun K. is asking for her first loan of $300 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticides to maintain her farm. 

In the photo, Mrs. Noeun K. is at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm.

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma L. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 39 years old. Erma is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Erma owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling pillows, pillow cases, bed sheets & blankets in the local community. Erma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Erma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Erma is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like blankets & pillow cases. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Erma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like blankets & pillow cases.

loans.name: Sotheary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sotheary C. and her husband are teachers. In addition, she also weaves silk at home (as pictured above) when she is not at school and her husband raises cows. The couple has been marred since 2006 and has two young sons. They live across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia

Sotheary is asking for a Kiva loan of $1,200 to purchase silk material for her weaving business. She will use a part of the loan to buy one more cow to raise.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her weaving business and buy another cow to raise.

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Modesta is a married with nine children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Modesta is 46 years old and has five children who are in school. She has a food vending business in the Philippines. Modesta requested a PHP 19,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Modesta has been in this business for 25 years. In the future, Modesta would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food vending business.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia A. is 45 years old and married with three school-aged children. Leticia is a farmer working in the Philippines. She earns PHP 3,000 per month. 

Leticia is asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to pay for the preparation of their vegetable crop. Leticia has been growing vegetables for almost 18 years.

In the future, Leticia hopes to have a large crop of vegetables in order to earn a higher income to finance the education of their children. She hopes that someday she can start another kind of business through the continuous assistance of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for preparing their vegetable plantation

loans.name: Eang

texts.en:
Eang Y. has been raising pigs since she was single. To support her family, Eang Y. spends most of her time feeding many piglets in a cage behind her house as well as growing rice on her own farmland.  

Eang Y.’s husband sells firewood in and around his community. They are blessed with four children. One of them assists her husband in selling firewood and another one is employed as a garment factory worker in Phnom Penh City.

Eang Y. would like to request a loan from Kiva in order to buy a motorcycle for reducing the cost of hiring taxis.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for reducing the costs of hiring taxis.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou P. is 31 years old and still single. Marilou is a farmer working in the Philippines. She earns PHP 3,000 per month. 

Marilou is asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Marilou has been growing tomatoes for four years.

In the future, Marilou hopes to produce more tomatoes to sell and earn income to support her parents and to save for her future. She believes that with the continuous support of the Kiva lenders, she can start another kind of business someday.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey R. (pictured with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Meun Mak, live across the Mekong River, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have one son and two daughters. All of them are in school. 

Srey has been a silk weaver for more thirty years, while her husband has been a construction worker for more than two years. She hopes to continue her weaving business, so she is asking for another loan of $800 to purchase silk materials. She will use a part of the loan to buy a cow to raise.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her weaving business and buy a cow to raise.

loans.name: Banzragch

texts.en: Banzragch is 54-year-old widow and lives with her five children in a house in Zavhan province, Mongolia. Her older three children are all grown up and work in public and private companies. Her younger two daughters go to a college and a secondary school. She manages a vegetable trading business in her town. She has been planting and harvesting vegetables for 31 years and became expert in her field. Now she owns one hectare land where she plants daily-consumed vegetables and large amount of garlic. She is a hard-working woman who says, "Last year all my planted garlic was stolen. So this year I want to have my own storage house in order to preserve all my vegetables." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to  build a storage house for her business.

loans.use: To build a store house.

loans.name: Doren

texts.en:
Mrs. Doren S. (pictured with her loom) is a 34-year-old and her husband, Mr. Solyying Yeang is a 33-year-old. They live in a village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They just have one young son.   

Doren and her husband are silk weavers. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase silk materials for her and her husband’s weaving business and buy a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and buy a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Yean

texts.en:
Yean L. resides in the Baray district of Kompong Tom province. She is a married woman who has four children; three of them are employed in various jobs. She has spent her life farming. Aside from this, she raises a few piglets for additional income. 

Her husband also helps Yean L. in the same business. From their rice farm, they can make a profit of around $7.50 a day. 

Yean L. is going to use her loan to buy a buffalo to help her in the field.

loans.use: to buy a buffalo.

loans.name: Saparkul's Group

texts.en:
Saparkul A. is the leader of this group. She is 33 and married to a taxi driver. Together they are bringing up five children: three daughters and two sons. All the children study at school. In order to earn additional money for the family budget the family breeds livestock. They make money by reselling livestock animals after fattening. In this way the family earns additional 7000 soms per month. 

With money received from the loan. Saparkul wants to increase the number of livestock and purchase more sheep for breeding. In the future she wants to improve the family living conditions and build a big house for the family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Uulkan's Group

texts.en:
Uulkan H. is the treasurer of this group. She is 48 and married to a constructor. She has a son, 12, who studies at school. Ten years ago in order to earn additional money for the family budget, the family started cultivating agricultural products. Selling some part of the harvest each month, Uulkan earns an additional 3000 soms. This business activity made it possible for her to save money and purchase a vehicle for the family. With money received from the loan, Uulkan wants to purchase a variety of seeds for farming. In the future she plans to start building a summer kitchen.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of seeds.

loans.name: Huon

texts.en:
Huon R. is 31 years old and has been selling fresh fish next to her village for more than two years. She sells fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing or buys them from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She is married to Houn Nat, 30, who works at fishing in and around the lakes of his community. 

Currently, his fishing is temporarily interrupted because his boat and other fishing equipment are broken. Because of this, Huon R. requested a loan to buy a new boat and additional fishing equipment. In the photograph, Huon R., her husband, and their three small kids are pictured all together in front their house.

loans.use: to buy a new boat and additional fishing equipment.

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
Venus U. is from the village of Balite, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 34 years old. Venus is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Venus owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, coffee, soap, chocolate & milk powder in the local community. Venus has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Venus joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Venus has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Venus is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Venus from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia B. is from the village of Imbatuhon, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Lilia is widowed and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks & other delicacies like rice cake or "bibingka" in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like powdered rice, coconut milk & sugar. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed like powdered rice, coconut milk & sugar.

loans.name: Aijan's Group

texts.en:
Aijan T. is the leader of this group. She is 42 and married to a driver. Her husband earns money by transporting passengers from Balykchi to Bishkek. Together they are bringing up three daughters and a son. The oldest daughter and the son study at university and the other children are at school.

Aijan herself works as a librarian at school. Eight years ago she was selling grocery products at the market, and then she saved some money and purchased a mini-bus “Mercedes Sprinter” for her husband. Since that moment her husband has been working as a driver. Aijan applied for the loan because they need money to purchase tires for the truck. In the future she wants to improve their living conditions and provide all her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase tires for the truck.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
Suon P. is a 61-year-old widow who now lives with her two single children. She stays at home to manage the family housework as well as selling some fruit to her neighbors. Her youngest daughter also helps in the fruit-selling business. The other produces Khmer noodles at home. 

Suon P. thinks that it is time to look for extra revenue, which she proposes to do by selling fruit at the market, but she lacks funds to do that. In order to deal with this issue, Suon P. would like to ask for loan to buy additional fruits for selling.

loans.use: to buy additional fruits for selling.

loans.name: Rhesa

texts.en:
Rhesa R. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 51 years old. Rhesa is widowed and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Rhesa owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, biscuits, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Rhesa has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rhesa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rhesa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rhesa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods & snack foods. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rhesa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods & snack foods.

loans.name: Sanoat

texts.en:
Sanoat is a hard-working woman who is married and has four children. Her husband left for Russia to work and for 10 years she has been running her farming business. Now Sanoat is the only breadwinner, considering that her husband works away from their country. So for that reason she cultivates potatoes and sells them. In this business her son helps her in order to improve their standard of living.

 Sanoat would like to get a loan of 10,000 Somoni for purchasing fertilizer for her land which allows her to get a good harvest. It is the first loan which she has requested and she hopes that the lenders will support her.   
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Lieu's Group

texts.en:
Lieu T. T. D. is 41 years old and has two children.  They live in Hoi Phu village. The income she earns from being a farmer is not enough to cover  her family's expenses. Therefore, she also makes bamboo brooms to sell, which supplements her daily income. She has been in this business for four years and earns 100,000 VND profit per day, which helps her improve her family's standard of living. Lieu is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy  bamboo to increase the quantity of brooms she makes. 

Hoa T. P. is 45 years old and has two children. She makes brooms to sell in the wholesale market. She is requesting a loan of 7,630,000 VND to buy materials.

Thao T. P. is 43 years old and has two children. She runs a business that focuses on making bamboo brooms. She is requesting a loan of 7,630,000 VND to buy bamboo.
 
Trang T. C. is 30 years old and has one child. She makes brooms to sell in the local market. She is requesting a loan of  5,014,000 VND to buy materials.

Lan T. C. is 47 years old and has one child. She is a rice farmer. In her free time, she makes brooms to earn extra income. She is requesting a loan of 5,104,000 VND to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: to purchase bamboo for brooms

loans.name: Lian

texts.en: Lian is 26 years old and married with two children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Lian is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for 10 years and also earns additional income from food vending. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en: Perlita is married and works hard to support five children with her sari sari store in the Philippines. Perlita requested a PHP 1,800 loan through NWTF to buy an Envirofit cookstove. She is getting the stove because she wants to lessen the amount of firewood that she uses when cooking food for her family. Perlita is aware that by using the cookstove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health-hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: To purchase an Envirofit cookstove

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita works hard to support five children. She is married and has a sugarcane farm in the Philippines. Nenita has requested a PHP 3,500 loan through NWTF to buy a solar lamp. She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have backup light in case of emergency. Nenita is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health-hazard risks to her family.

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma is 44 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell.

Erma has borrowed and repaid 7 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari sari store for six years and also earns an income from cooked food vending.

Erma aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Lurcille

texts.en:
Lurcille B. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 52 years old. Lurcille is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Lurcille owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products  including fish like sardines & milk fish in the local community. Lurcille has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lurcille joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lurcille has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Lurcille is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish like sardines & mackerel. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Lurcille from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish like sardines & mackerel.

Agnes has been raising pigs for two years now and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain her activity.

In the future, Agnes would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

She has a "carenderia" (restaurant) business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from her general store. Annabelle has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her restaurant.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sigara Group

texts.en:
Christina N., who is in her early 30s, is married with three daughters. Two of her daughters go to school. She has been selling liquid soap, sarongs and perfumes since 2008.  She works from 10:00 am to 2:00 pm daily (just for four hours because she has a small baby to care for).  She sells her products door-to-door and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Christina's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to sell liquid soap, sarongs and perfumes and has paid back her loans successfully.  She hopes for a loan to increase her inventory of liquid soap and sarongs and will start selling fabrics and no more perfumes. Her dream is to buy land with her husband one day.

Christina will share this loan with her loan group "Sigara" (Kiswahili for Cigarettes) which has a total of 16 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

In the picture, Christina is first on the left in the second row.

loans.use: To buy liquid soap, sarongs and fabric to sell.

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy materials like fishing nets, etc for her fishing business.
Emilia has been in this business for seven years. Emilia earns more income from fish net making & buying & selling of used clothes.

Emilia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. Her dream is to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy materials like fishing nets, etc for her fishing business

texts.en:
Evelyn B. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old. Evelyn is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture making and selling snacks & other delicacies like sandwiches, cheese & rice cakes in the local community. Karen C. is a married woman with one school-aged child. She is now 33 years old. Karen sells food like sweetened candies to the people in her community. She has been in this business for more than three years and she earns approximately PHP 4,000 per month.

Karen is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients to make more candies to sell.

In the future, Karen hopes to improve the business she manages in order to earn more income to support the education of their child. She is thankful that Kiva lenders are always there to improve her small business, and she hopes that through patience and hard work, she will become successful in her business someday.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make more candies to sell

loans.name: Zamira

texts.en:
Zamira B. is married and has three children. Along with her son, Zamira is engaged in animal husbandry, which she has been doing for more than 10 years. Besides this business, she also sews national woman’s dresses. Zamira is requesting a loan of 12,000 Somoni, which will be used to  purchase cattle.  She will use the income to improve her living conditions. 
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Nugzar

texts.en:
Nugzar D. lives in the village of Sajavakho, Martvili District. He is 48 years old. Nugzar lives with his mother, sister-in-law and his nephew.

Nugzar is a tinsmith by profession. He designs ovens, iron railings, and iron ladders.  He sells the products locally as well as in nearby villages. Along with the above-mentioned, Nugzar helps other family members in their dairy farm and vegetable growing. His average monthly income is 600 Laris. 

With the requested credit, Nugzar plans to purchase iron materials, which will be used to produce ovens and railings. Cost of goods sold per oven is approximately 125 Laris, while the selling price is 300 Laris. Nugzar plans to reinvest the profit in the same business and increase the inventory in his workshop.

loans.use: to purchase metal materials for his workshop.

loans.name: Irakli

texts.en:
Irakli D. lives in the village of Maghlaki, Tskaltubo District. He lives with his big family: his wife Tamar, his parents and two sons (15 and 16 years old). Irakli’s sons go to a local school. 

Irakli heads up the agricultural farm owned by the family, though Tamar and Irakli’s parents are actively involved in farming activities. They have six greenhouses, where they grow greens. The end product is sold to exporters of greens. Greenhouses are also used for growing tomatoes. Tomatoes are sold on the local market. In addition to the above-mentioned, the family has three cows, whose dairy products are sold on the local market. 

With the requested credit, Irakli plans to purchase fertilizers and also pay for the tractor for tilling the land. After fertilization the amount and quality of the greens, as well as tomatoes, will go in a positive direction. It will positively affect the income of the family. 

Irakli and Tamar hope that they will have a good season and harvested products will be sold profitably. Part of the profit will be used for financing the studies of their sons and the rest will be reinvested in the agricultural business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and to pay for tilling the land.

Wijdan's husband has been a taxi driver for 10 years, and his car needs urgent maintenance. Wijdan took out a loan from FATEN to help her husband cover the expenses that will increase his profit and the hours of work which will help him afford a big family's expenses.

loans.use: to do car maintenance and replace the engine.

loans.name: Iuza

texts.en:
Iuza comes from the village of Gora, Imereti Region. He is 54 years old and lives in his home-village with his wife Medea, their 27-year-old daughter and 21-year-old son. 

Iuza G. works in local factory as a specialist and also is actively involved in the family’s agricultural activities. In particular, family has two milk cows and produces cheese, which is sold locally. Also the family has a vineyard (600 grape vines) and sells grapes. Iuza produces wine and sells it in the village. Medea and their son are also involved in the family business. Their daughter works as a sales person. 

Iuza and Medea plan to diversify the family’s farming activities. In particular, they plan to construct a greenhouse where two products will be grown – tomatoes in summer and greens in the winter period. This will significantly increase the income of the family. According the Iuza’s calculations this business will be profitable and increase the monthly income of the family, now 1000 Laris, by at least 50%.

loans.use: to purchase materials for greenhouse construction.

loans.name: Maaya Tukolerewamu Group

texts.en: Lillian is the woman with her hand raised who leads this loan group. She is 32 years old, married to a businessman, lives in an area known as Kyenjojo and is applying for this loan to buy airtime on the local phone network to resell to her customers. She dreams of earning enough money to educate her children and having enough capital to start other businesses. Because few people own mobile phones in her area, she has also worked as a maize farmer. The loan group that Lillian leads is called Maaya Tukolerewamu and members guarantee each other's loans.

loans.use: To buy air time to resell to her customers.

loans.name: Mercelinda

texts.en:
Mercelinda O. lives in the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old, widowed and has four school-aged children. She earns a living by making and selling snacks and local delicacies such as balot or hard-boiled duck eggs. She has been in this line of work for more than four years and earns about 4,500 PHP a month.

Earlier this year, Mercelinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for a loan, her first, for 4,000 PHP to buy ingredients such as duck eggs. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Gina
