Gina C. lives in the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She makes a living by making and selling popular local delicacies such as puto or rice cakes. She has been in this line of work for more than two years and earns about 6,000 PHP a month.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 36 years old, single and has four children who range in age from 6 to 16. She is hardworking and her family's sole breadwinner. She lives in a rented house in an area known as Karuguuza and is committed to pay her children's school fees by running the restaurant we see here. She has been in this line of work for 10 years and has earned enough money to buy a plot of land. Because food prices are high today, she dreams of opening up a second business, a hair salon. She is applying for this loan to buy equipment such as plates and chairs.

loans.use: To purchase equipment such as plates and chairs.

loans.name: Jonabeth

texts.en: Jonabeth S. is from the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Jonabeth is widowed and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jonabeth buys and sells ready-to-wear clothing, sandals and shoe products from NATASHA and AVON. Jonabeth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2011, Jonabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonabeth is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional blouses, t-shirts and sandals. This will be the first loan taken out by Jonabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. loans.name: 13 Đông Vệ Group

texts.en:
"Thi N. Thị (69) is a 61 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá.  Thi is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 13 Đông Vệ (08.01.13 Đông Vệ).

Thi is married and has 2 adult -aged children.  To making a living, Thi owns and operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of food products in the local community.  Thi has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2010, Thi joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Thi has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,253,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6,159,600 VND which will be used to invest in renovating the business.  The loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Thi plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  N. Thị Tâm (70) is a 38 year-old female who is requesting a 6,159,600 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.

2.  N. Thị Hương (71) is a 45 year-old female who is requesting a 6,159,600 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

loans.name: 12  Đông Vệ Group

texts.en:
Liên T. Thị (0) is a 45-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. She is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 12 Đông Vệ (08.01.12 Đông Vệ).

Liên is married and has 3 school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling clothing and shoe products in the local community.  Liên has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,500,000 VND a month from it.

In 2010, Liên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liên has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,253,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, which was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,159,600 VND which will be used to invest in renovating the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Liên from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in Thanh Hoa province.

Liên T. Thị (0) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Liên là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 8 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 12-chợ Nam Thành - Đông Vệ (08.01.12-Đông Vệ).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán áo quần & giày dép trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Liên thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 7 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Liên kiếm được khoảng 3,500,000 VND.  Vào 2010, Liên đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Liên đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,253,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,159,600 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

5.  Lê Thị Thu (67) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,159,600 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.name: Ronna Mae

texts.en:
Ronna Mae G. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 22 years old, single and has 1 infant. Ronna Mae owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop, buying and selling daily use products such as canned goods, junk foods, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Ronna Mae has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Ronna Mae joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronna Mae is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods and beverages. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Ronna Mae from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods and beverages.

loans.name: Sbina

texts.en: Sabina is a 52-year-old widow with 4 children living in a rented house in Hioma, Uganda. She has no other dependents and her family goal is to educate her children to attain a degree as a minimum qualification. Sabina has been running a retail business for 10 years but she faces a challenge of high food prices. Her desire is to have a wholesale business. Sabina needs the loan to buy sugar, rice, soap and cooking oil to sell in her shop.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, soap and cooking oil to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Priscah

texts.en:
Priscah is a mother of 4 children aged between 13 and 22 years, with the last two still in school. She is 53 years old and has been farming in the Kitale area of Western Kenya for the last 10 years, producing milk and selling to the local market.

Priscah has made a second loan request with Juhudi Kilimo, amounting to 30,000 KES, to help her venture into poultry farming by making an initial purchase of poultry birds. She says the poultry market is booming and she believes she will be able to earn income that will see her children and grandchildren through school. She is optimistic the two businesses will continue thriving. Priscah notes that diseases are still a challenge and need serious mitigation strategies. She is glad with Juhudi's loan services.

loans.use: To buy poultry.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester Sigua is a married woman with four adult children. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products. Ester has had this business for seven years.

Ester is requesting a loan of 18,000 PHP to buy products like condiments, soap, toothpaste, etc. to sell in the community.

In the future, Ester hopes that her business improves and expands in order to sustain the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy products like condiments, soap, toothpaste, etc.

loans.name: Tynymkan's Group

texts.en:
Tynymkan M. is the leader of this group. She is 65 and, unfortunately, is a widow. She has a son, 40, who is handicapped. Sixteen years ago, Tynymkan started to breed farm animals. At present, she has two cattle and twelve sheep. She has applied for a loan because she wants to improve her living conditions. She wants to purchase plastic windows and install them in her house. In the future, Tynymkan wants to increase the number of livestock and dreams of finding a cure for her son.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase plastic windows.

loans.name: Xuan's Group

texts.en:
Xuan T. T. is 41 years old with 2 children. She is the group leader of a 5-member group. Xuan T. T. is a farmer who grows rice and vegetables. These agricultural products are used to feed her family and are also sold in the local market to earn a daily income. Xuan T. T. hopes to use this 5,014,000 VND loan to buy more fertilizer and seeds to improve productivity.

Mai T. N. is 30 years old with 2 children. She runs a hair cutting shop at her house. She wants a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy more clothes.

Hang T. N. is 48 years old with 2 children. She grows rice and vegetables in a paddy of 4,500 square meters and raises 100 chickens for meat. She wants a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy chicken feed.

Duoc T. N. is 41 years old with 2 children. She runs a small grocery shop. She wants a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy more kinds of products to meet her customers' demand.

Doi T. N. is 40 years old. She grows rice and vegetables to sell in the local market. She is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds to improve productivity.

loans.name: Rolivie

texts.en:
Rolivie L. is from Talairon, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. Rolivie runs a dried fish retail business in the local community. Rolivie has been engaged in her business for 15 years and earns approximately 1,100 PHP a month from it.

Rolivie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which she will use to purchase more dried fish to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Rolivie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more dried fish.

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en:
Doreen, 41 years old, is married with 7 children aged 5 to 21 years old. She lives in her own house in Hoima, Uganda. Her spouse is a driver. Doreen has one dependent who is her grandchild. Her family goal is to educate her children and see them able to sustain themselves.

Doreen has operated a produce business for 5 years. She started by growing tobacco and then later on opened her current business selling maize. She faces a challenge of the business being seasonal. Her desire is to diversify into selling beans and groundnuts. Doreen needs a loan to purchase maize to sell.

loans.use: To buy maize.

texts.en: Tadeo, 29 years old, is married and a father of 3 children aged 5, 3 and 2 years old. His spouse is a teacher. Tadeo lives with his family of 5 in his own home in Hoima, Uganda. Tadeo has been employed by the Hoima Diocese communication department for 2 years and earns a regular salary. His family goal is to establish a side business to add to the salaries he and his wife earn. Tadeo needs a loan to purchase land for farming.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife C. is from the village of Poblcaion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Marife owns and operates a business buying and selling tuna fish products in the local community. Marife has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Marife joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marife has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Marife is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional stocks of tuna fish products. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marife from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of tuna fish products.

loans.name: Dominique

texts.en:
Dominique is 28 years old. He is single. He owns a shop in which he sells a variety of items such as cooking oil, beans, rice and other items that are commonly wanted at home. With this business he could afford to buy himself a piece of land and equipment for installing electricity. 

Dominique is requesting a loan to buy more items to fill his store, such as rice, beans and cooking oil, and make more profits in order to improve his standard of living.

loans.use: to buy items such as beans and rice for sale.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda Telan manages a general store where she sells different products that her co-villagers need. At the age of 53, Erlinda is married. Through the business, she earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Erlinda is requesting a loan of 13,000 PHP to purchase products such as canned goods, detergent, soaps and condiments to sell in their village.

In the future, Erlinda hopes that her business will progress to support the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy products such as canned goods, detergents, soaps and condiments to sell

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is a resident and a farmer in Kitale area, Western Kenya. He is married with four children between 5 and 14 years old, and has been in farming for eight years producing and selling milk, eggs and vegetables to the local market. He is also running a motorcycle transport business for additional income.

Benjamin has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He believes the cow will improve his milk production and help in the repayment of the loan, and eventually add an asset to the family, eventually uplifting the family living standards. He is optimistic with the business and plans to have five better breed cows in five years.

Benjamin says the cost of artificial insemination are still to high for farmers.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ameh

texts.en: Ameh is a 44 years old, a married man from Jenin. He lives with his wife and four children, two of whom are in school. In 2005, he bought his own Moving Stroller that he sells products on. He hopes that with this loan he will be able to buy a refrigerator and products which will help him in increasing his income.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator and products which will help him in increasing his income.

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en: Immaculee is 43 years old. She has seven children between the ages of 4 and 21 years old, and they are all in school. Her husband operates a motorcycle as a source of income. Immaculate sells food stuffs such as cassava and she also sells goats. This has enabled her pay school fees for her children and to feed them as well. She is requesting money to purchase cassava as well as goats for sale, while with the profits she plans to buy more goats.

loans.use: to buy cassava and goats.

loans.name: Askarbek's Group

texts.en:
Askarbek M., 52, is a member of this group. He is married and has three children: two sons and a daughter. The daughter is a student, the first son is a driver and the second earns money by repairing mobile phones. Askarbek’s wife provides sewing services. She takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national blankets, pillows, cloth and dressmaking supplies. In order to contribute money to family budget, Askarbek works as a driver and earns 200 soms a day. The family also cultivates agricultural products. With money received from the loan, Aslarbek wants to purchase lucerne seeds; for this purpose he applied for the loan. In the future, he wants to see his daughter get wed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase lucerne seeds.

loans.name: Hanh's Group

texts.en:
Hanh T. L., 32, has two children who are in high school, and is living in Yen phong district. Being a farmer, she sees that the income from agricultural activity is not enough to cover all her family expenditure. In 2006, she decided to open a shop that sells CDs, records, mobiL. phones and phone cards. Her shop was much developed when she accessed our loan in 2009. Since that time, she has passed five loan cycles successfully. For the new loan cycL., she requires a loan of 9,184,000 Vietnamese dong to buy more new design mobiL. phones to attract customers.

Lien T. N. is 25 years old with a child. She has a shop that sells cosmetic products at her house. Now she needs a loan of 7,392,000 Vietnamese dong

Huong T. T. is 23 years old with a child. She has a shop that sells electrical devices and water equipment. She needs to have a loan 5,152,000 Vietnamese dong.

loans.use: to buy more new design mobile phones to attract customers.

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en: Beatha is 32 years old. She has two children, 6 and 8 years old. Beatha is married and her husband is a barber. Beatha owns a hair-cutting salon in which her husband works and she has owned this salon for five years and it has enabled her to feed her family and to expand her business. She is requesting a loan to buy some equipment such as cotton and a hair-cutting machine.

loans.use: to buy equipment and materials for the hair-cutting machine.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase materials for weaving modern Afghani carpets.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 25, is a farmer living in the Kitale area of western Kenya. He is married though not yet blessed with children. He has been active in mixed farming for the past three years, producing and selling eggs, tomatoes and onions to the local market.

John has requested a loan of 31,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This will be his second loan with Juhudi Kilimo. He says the milk produced will supplement his family meals and the income generated will be used to expand his business so as to cater for the family's future needs, such as education. He hopes to make a strong foundation for his family out of the farming business. John adds that water is still a challenge during dry seasons. 

He is focusing on repaying this loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Nicodemus Leseiyio

texts.en:
Nicodemus Leseiyio O. W., 33, is married with two children. He has been a wheat farmer for the past three years. 

He has applied for his first loan from KADET Ltd. to buy farming supplies, namely wheat seeds and also land preparations. With the profits generated, he plans to pay school fees for his children.

Nicodemus dreams of becoming a prominent farmer. He is an assiduous man who works with effort to attain more despite limited resources.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies.

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine, 30, has two children, aged two and six. The older child is in school, while the younger is still at home. Francine owns a shop in which she sells sodas, cooking oil, rice, etc. She works together with her husband. She has had this business for two years and it has enabled her to improve her family's standard of living. 

Francine is requesting a loan to buy more soft drinks, such as sodas and food stuffs, such as rice and cooking oil.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks and food stuffs for resale.

loans.name: Maripe Ole

texts.en:
Maripe Ole N., 50, has been a farmer for the last eight years. He is married to a housewife and blessed with six children.

He learned about KADET Ltd. from KADET marketing in his neighborhood. This will be his third loan and he plans to use it to purchase farm supplies. He intends to re-invest the returns from the loan in farming and to buy a bigger farm.

His dream is to be the best and most well-known farmer in Narok. He is an industrious man who can do well if funded.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Janviere

texts.en: Janviere is 21 and has a one year old child. She works together with her husband selling milk. They have done this business for one year and it has enabled her to pay school fees for her family and to improve their standard of living. She is requesting a loan to purchase more quantities of fresh milk and hence make more profit. With her savings and the profits, she plans to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy fresh milk.

loans.name: La Paix Virunga Group

texts.fr: Furaha L. est entrepreneur, Leader du groupe d’affaire « La paix Virunga »,  âgée de 40 ans, mariée, mère de 7 enfants. Son mari est un Officier de la police nationale congolaise. La cliente Furaha L.  est vendeuse des Farines de maïs  (semoules) au marché central de Virunga.  Il ya 2 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Elle démarra son business avec  50$ reçu de l’IMF Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec  5 sacs de farines de maïs (semoules)  à marchander.  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, scolariser ses enfants.  La cliente Furaha L. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire «  La paix Virunga» est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en:
Furaha L. is an entrepreneur, and leader of the business group "La paix Virunga” (Virunga Peace), which is composed mainly of women. She is 40 years old, married, and the mother of seven (7) children. Her husband is an officer of the national Congolese police. 

Furaha L. sells maize flour (semolina) at the central market of Virunga. She has been doing this for two years. She started her business with a sum of $50 received from the Hekima MFI. 

She will use this new loan to buy five bags of maize flour for resale. She also plans to expand her business, and have her children attend school. 

Furaha L. wishes to thank the Hekima MFI for helping the less fortunate who cannot turn to traditional banks.

loans.use: to buy five bags of maize flour (semolina)

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for the construction of a poultry unit and to buy more birds.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase cool beverages, fresh fruits and other items for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to prepare land and buy maize seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more sheep and farm inputs

loans.name: Therese

texts.en:
Therese is 43 years old. She has nine children aged between one and twenty-five years old, seven of whom are in school. The eldest has completed school, while the youngest has not yet begun school. 

Therese sells food stuffs and her husband works with her. They have run this business together for six years and it has enabled them to pay fees for their children and to feed them. She is requesting a loan to buy more food stuffs, such as beans and sorghum, in order to expand her business.

Her future plans are to open up a wholesale shop and make more profit.

loans.use: to buy food stuffs, such as beans and sorghum for her food business

loans.name: Venancia

texts.en:
Venancia is 32 years old. She has six children aged between four and sixteen years old, five of whom are in school. 

Venancia's husband is a carpenter, while she owns a shop in which she sells rice, sugar, soap etc. As part of this business Venancia bought a piece of land and also a house. She is requesting a loan to buy rice, sugar and soap in order to make more profit. 

With these additional profits, together with her savings, she will buy another piece of land and pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: to buy items for her shop such as rice,sugar and soap

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama K. is a mother of five and makes her living selling slippers and bowls in the Elmina. She doesn’t own a store and sells her wares the traditional, mobile way: balancing them on her head and walking around the villages. She has been doing this for the past 12 years.

To provide better for her children, Ama wants to increase her earnings. She plans to do so by expanding her business. A loan from Kiva will allow her to purchase a greater variety of slippers and increase her stock of bowls. She also wants to add clothing to her items for sale.

She plans to save up her extra earnings for her children’s future, particularly their university education.

loans.use: to purchase a greater variety of slippers and increase her stock of bowls for sale

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame K. has been preparing and selling kenkey in Elmina for three years now. Kenkey is a local and very popular staple made from fermented maize dough, usually eaten with pepper sauce and fish. Maame wants to expand her business and plans to use her loan from Kiva to purchase more maize, which will allow her to prepare more kenkey for sale.

Maame has three children, and her earnings pay for their school fees and the household expenses. She plans to save any extra earnings for her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase more maize to allow her to prepare more kenkey for sale.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel, a 34-year-old married father of four children, three of whom are already in school, has been a farmer for four years in the Kitale area in Western Kenya. His farm produces milk, tomatoes, and sugarcane, all of which are sold to the local market. He relies fully on farming for his family's upkeep.

His first loan with Juhudi Kilimo promptly repaid, Samuel is requesting a new loan of 31,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the milk produced will be consumed by the family as well as sold to provide for the other family basic needs including education for the children. He believes the loan will have a positive impact on the family.

Samuel says that the main challenge faced by dairy farmers is animal feed shortages during dry seasons.

loans.use: To buy  and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lela

texts.en:
Lela G. comes from the village of Patriketi, Imereti Region. She is 29 years old, unmarried and lives with her parents and 25-year-old brother. 

Lela’s family earns a living with agricultural activities. In particular, they have a greenhouse, where greens and vegetables are grown. In the period of October-May the greenhouse is full of fresh greens. The end-product is sold to exporters of greens, who export to neighboring countries. In June-September the greenhouse is used for cucumber- and tomato-growing. Harvested vegetables are sold on the local open market by Lela. 

Also the family has put up an iron construction for a second greenhouse. With the requested credit Lela plans to purchase polyethylene materials to cover the construction and make it ready for the vegetable growing season. The other part of the loan will be used for purchasing fertilizers. 

When the second greenhouse is functional, the income of the family, which today amounts to 700 Laris per month, will double. This will allow them to improve their living conditions and also reinvest in the future for further development of the farm.

loans.use: to purchase polyethylene materials for a greenhouse.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa E. runs a provision store in Elmina, a fishing town in Ghana’s Central Region. She has run this store for 20 years and she sells a variety of items, including soap, tinned food, toilet rolls, eggs, slippers and diapers.
 
Adjoa plans to grow her business further by adding more items. She believes that more variety and also larger quantities of certain items will cater to the needs of her clients. She also hopes to attract some new customers. With her Kiva loan, she intends to purchase items such as milk, Milo (a brand of malted milk) and sugar. 

Adjoa intends to reinvest some of the additional earnings and save up the rest for her family’s future. She has three children and her income pays for their schooling and the family’s household expenses.

loans.use: to purchase items such as milk, Milo and sugar for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more cartons of fish.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy some essential materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa C. is married and has eight children. 

For the past 10 years, she has been supplementing her husband’s income by selling kenkey in the fishing town of Elimina. Kenkey is a popular Ghanaian staple made from fermented maize dough. It is usually served with pepper sauce and fish.
 
Theresa is keen to expand her food business and plans to use her Kiva loan to purchase more maize. This will allow her to prepare and sell more kenkey. She plans to save up any extra money she earns for her eight children’s future.

loans.use: to purchase more maize.

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en:
Baktygul M. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and married to a farmer. She has a daughter and two sons. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family. The first son works as a security guard and the second son studies at school. 

Baktygul, together with her husband, cultivates agricultural products. She has been doing it since 1991. Her husband also earns money for the family budget by transporting passengers from Balykchi to Bishkek. 

With money received from the loan, Baktygul wants to purchase potato and wheat seeds. In the future, she plans to improve the family’s living conditions and provide her younger son a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato and wheat seeds.

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en:
Epiphanie is 27 years old and she has a 6-month-old baby. 

She owns a general store in which she sells soap and Irish potatoes on a wholesale scale. She works together with her husband and they have had this business for one year. 

This business has enabled them build a small house for themselves. 

Epiphanie is requesting a loan to buy a large quantity of Irish potatoes and some soap, which will enable her to make more profits.

loans.use: to buy Irish potatoes and soap.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more cartons of fish.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah A. runs a provisions store in Elmina, a fishing town in Ghana’s Central Region. Her income from this business, which she’s been in for two years now, helps pay for her three children’s school fees and the household utility bills. Her husband is a farmer. 

She sells a variety of items, including soap, tinned tomatoes, tinned sardines, soft drinks, diapers and toothbrushes. 

Sarah is keen to increase the variety of items she sells to attract more customers and to keep existing ones coming back. Her loan from Kiva will allow her to do just that. She plans to add items such as Milo (a brand of malted milk), sugar and milk, among other items, to her inventory.

loans.use: to increase the variety of items she sells.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo K. lives in the Baray district of Cambodia. She is a 42-year-old married woman who sells merchandise by peddling. She has been operating this business since 1995 and makes around $3.75 each day. 

To help Keo K. with their increasing expenses, her husband works at a rubber plantation. Besides selling, Keo K. has been planting a few crops on her farmland. The rainy season is coming now and Keo K. is asking for a loan to plant potato crops. 

Keo K. is a mother of two children who are both in school.

loans.use: to plant potato crops

loans.name: Rwengwe Tukore Group

texts.en:
Victor B. is a 43-year-old business man who subsists on his agriculture business. He mostly grows and sells tea leaves in Rwengwe-Kihihi. He has been in this business for the last nine years and he says he joined this business on sensing the ready tea market in most of Western Uganda.

His farming gardens are mostly full of growing tea. Hard work and determination have been the towers of strength for this happily married father of six. He says weekly his tea sales business profits are to the tune of 100,000 UGX. He says with this loan, he is going to purchase fertilizers for his tea gardens.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for his tea crop.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
For the past 10 years, Agnes B. has been selling kenkey to make a living. (Kenkey is a popular Ghanaian staple made from fermented maize dough, usually eaten with pepper sauce and fried fish). 

She is married to a farmer and her income helps pay for their three children’s school fees.
 
Agnes wants to increase her earnings and plans to do so by increasing the production and sale of kenkey. Her Kiva loan will allow her to purchase more maize and other ingredients. 

She plans to reinvest any extra earnings back into her business for further growth. 

On the floor, on her right is a bundle of plantain leaves for the kenkey. On her left is the container she uses to boil the kenkey.

loans.use: to purchase more maize and other ingredients.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for more poultry in the farm.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is married to a farmer and they have three children. To help her husband with the household expenses, Mary sells cassava and plantains in Elmina, which is a fishing town in Ghana’s Central Region. 

To improve her earnings, Mary wants to boost her sales. She needs a loan from Kiva to allow her to purchase more cassava, plantains and other food items. She intends to reinvest any extra earnings back into her business for further growth. Ultimately, she wants to earn and save enough to put her children through university.

loans.use: to purchase more cassava, plantains and other food items.

loans.name: Ernest

texts.en: Ernest is 37 years old, and he has five children who are aged between 6 months and 12 years old; among them three are in school. His wife is a farmer and sells different kinds of items. He sells building stones/rocks and he has done this business for five years. From it he built a house in which he lives and a coffee tasting machine. He is requesting a loan to buy a piece of land on which he hopes to cut stones for sale. He plans to pay his children’s school fees with the profits he hopes to make.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land on which he hopes to cut building stones.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena B. sells kernel oil and cassava in Elmina, which is a coastal town in Ghana’s Central Region. She has been in this business for four years now. She extracts the kernel oil herself, through a process that involves several steps: she first takes the shells off the palm nuts. She then extracts the oil by heating the dried nuts to release the palm kernel oil. The released oil is skimmed from the top of the nuts. This process is continued until all the oil is skimmed out of the palm kernel. In the photograph, Abena is shown heating the kernel nuts. 

Abena is married to a farmer and they have four children. Her income helps pay their children’s school fees and the family’s utility bills. She needs a loan to expand her business. She plans to purchase more buy more kernel nuts and cassava to increase her sales. She intends to save some of the extra earnings for her children’s school fees and to reinvest the rest of it back into her business for further growth.

loans.use: to buy more palm kernel nuts and cassava to increase her sales.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more palm oil

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is 21 years old, and she has a one-year-old child. She is a tailor and she has done this business for five years. She works together with her husband. They do farming as well, and from this business they built a house in which they live. Diana is requesting a loan to buy more fabrics and make different styles of dresses for sale. With the profits, she plans to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy fabrics.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua K. sells cosmetics at Elmina, a fishing town in Ghana’s Central Region. She sells items such as talcum powder and slippers. Ekua does not own a shop and carries her wares in a metal container (as shown in the photograph), which she balances on her head. 

She wants to improve the selection of items she sells to attract more customers and improve her earnings. A loan from Kiva will allow her to buy more cosmetics for resale. Ekua intends to reinvest any extra earnings back into her business, which she has been in for two years, for further growth. 
She is married to a farmer and they have three children. Her earnings helps pay their kids’ school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more onions, soap, and peppers.

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 30 years old. She has two children  who are eight and six years old. She owns a store in which she sells foodstuffs such as beans, sorghum, and peanuts. She runs this business together with her husband. 

Francoise has run this business for three years and from that business, they built three small houses and they also bought a cow. She is requesting a loan to buy more foodstuffs such as beans, sorghum and peanuts.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs.

loans.name: Mery

texts.en:
Mery N. sells smoked fish in Elmina, which is a major fishing town in Ghana’s Central Region. She has been in this trade for three years now. 

She is married to a farmer and they have four children. Her income from selling smoked fish helps pay their children’s school fees and the household utility bills. 

To increase her earnings, Mery needs a loan from Kiva to allow her to purchase larger quantities of fish and boost her sales. She intends to reinvest any extra earnings from the increased sales back into her business. Her long-term goal is to ensure she has put aside enough to support her children through their university education.

loans.use: to purchase larger quantities of fish.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for more poultry.

loans.name: Cecilia Suapem  Aba

texts.en:
Cecilia Suapem Aba B. is a baker. She bakes pastries and moves about in the community of Elmina to sell them. She is a single parent. She has been in this baking business for three years. Cecilia uses her income to pay her child’s school fees and utility bills. 

Cecilia is requesting a loan to purchase bags of flour, oil and sugar to be able to bake on a larger scale for distribution and sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cecilia plans to build a snack bar by the roadside so she can attract more customers.

She has on her head a container of meat pies.

loans.use: to purchase bags of flour, oil and sugar.

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo is 57 years old and lives in the village of Dimi, Imereti Region. He lives with his wife Darejan, their son, daughter-in-law and 3-year-old granddaughter Lizi. 

The main source of income for the family comes from agricultural activities. In particular, they have a milk cow and a calf. Their cheese is sold on the local market. Also the family owns a vineyard with 1000 grape vines. Leo produces wine and sells it in the village. Along with the above-mentioned, Leo and Darejan own a grocery store in the village. 

With the requested credit the family plans to increase stock in trade in the store. This will increase the competitiveness of the store and attract more customers. The income of the family will increase and it will allow them to improve their living conditions. 

In the future the Grdzelidzes plan to invest more in the store and expand it.

loans.use: to pay for stock in trade for the grocery store.

loans.name: Jaqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline is 32 years old. She has four children who are ages 3-12 years old. They are all in school. Her husband is a soldier while Jacqueline sells a traditional fabric known as "kitenge". She has done this business for five years. She is requesting a loan to buy more traditional fabrics in order to make more profits. She plans to buy a piece of land from the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: to buy fabrics.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is a 30-year-old married woman who lives in Trinidad, Bohol with her family. She has two children aged three and two. Gina is a farmer and has been growing rice for three years. She sells her harvest to rice traders at her town. She usually earns 4000 PHP per month from doing this farming.

This loan will be used by Gina to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to have a stable business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Abenawa

texts.en:
Abenawa A. is married and has six dependents. She operates a provisions shop and as well cooks banku at Elmina for sale. Banku is a local dish made from corn dough and served hot with soup. She is married to a farmer. Together they feed, clothe, and educate her dependents. 

Her customers are demanding more items from her shop and so she is requesting a loan to meet their needs; she will use the loan to buy more provisions for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Abenawa plans to open another shop.

loans.use: to buy provisions for resale.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba O. sells (as a peddler) kid's clothes, slippers, and other items at Elmina. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a driver. Aba has been trading in this type of business for three years. She supports her husband in taking care of the home. Her loan will serve as in increase in income to buy more clothes, slippers, and shoes for resale. She anticipates reinvesting her additional profit.

loans.use: to buy more clothes, slippers, and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a 36-year-old married woman four children. The oldest child is 15 years old. 

Jocelyn has been in the business of raising hogs for more than three years. She plans to use her loan to purchase piglets, feed, and vitamins. Each month, Evelyn earns 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from her hog-raising business. 

In the future, Jocelyn hopes for her children to finish college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase piglets, feed, and vitamins

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to move her clothing shop into the city of Kabul

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 59 years old, she has nine children who are ages 20-40 years old. Only two are in school while the others are already married. Her husband is a farmer while Irene sells food stuffs such as beans, sorghum etc. This business has enabled her pay school fees for her children and build a house in which she stays. 

She is requesting a loan to buy more food and make more profits. She plans to open up a wholesale store in the market where she hopes to get more clients. With the profits she plans to feed her family and renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy food for resale
